reading_mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
The reading is a bit weird. It's the kun'yomi readings, where 一 is ひと and 筋 is すじ. Look back on the vocab words that use these readings to remember this one.

The reading is the み from 三つ and つ and 編む combined into one (or should I say three?) braids. Just watch out because this isn't みっつあみ, it's just みつあみ. Listen to the audio a few times to make sure you remember how it's spelled and pronounced!
The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Let's help <vocabulary>each other</vocabulary>. Maybe if we work <vocabulary>together</vocabulary> we can get rid of this <reading>tagger</reading> (たが) tagging graffiti all over our neighborhood.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The reading is the same as the word 傷.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

This word can also be read つるぎ, but in that case its meaning is limited to Western-style swords only. Because of the meaning difference, we only accept the けん reading (but you'll get another try if you enter つるぎ).
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Who is the one person who always seems <vocabulary>to be in high spirits</vocabulary>? <reading>Isa</reading>bel (いさ)! She's so positive and eager, even in the face of a challenge.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The やく gets changed to やっ.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. All I know is there's probably not a homonym for this word, for it is huge.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know the word 否定 as well.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This vocabulary word uses the same reading you learned with the kanji, plus the hiragana attached at the end.

The readings are the on'yomi reading. You've seen the on'yomi reading of 喜 before, though it may be hard to remember at this point. Maybe you can think about how when you reach this <vocabulary>seventy seventh birthday</vocabulary>, all you want is a <reading>key</reading> (き) to the city so you can do whatever you want.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The reading is the same as 垂らす.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. It might also help to know the kanji in 寿司 are 当て字 (remember those?). They have nothing to do with sushi, so they're just being used here for their sound.

You did learn the reading of 寿, but the reading for 命 is an exception. When you think of a lifespan, think of how that affects everyone. Me, you... well, just those things. Combine them both into <reading>myou</reading> (みょう). That is who the lifespan affects. Myou!
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The reading is 尊敬 plus 語 put together.
The reading is the kun'yomi readings of 山 and 中, then the on'yomi reading of 湖.
As for <vocabulary>myself</vocabulary>? I'm not Bob. <reading>oh no, Ray</reading> (おのれ), Ray is my name.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is also the reading you learned. How nice! But if you don't remember it, what a <vocabulary>shame</vocabulary>. What an <vocabulary>embarrassment</vocabulary> this must be for you.
When you're <vocabulary>ashamed</vocabulary> it's even worse when someone laughs at you: <reading>ha</reading> (は) ha ha!"
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The reading is the same as 暮らす.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned 暮らす, so if you can remember that, you should be able to remember this one too!
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. This will be particularly useful for names, as there's a lot of names with 杉.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You are given some soup. You take a bite and your mouth is cut clean off. That is because you're eating <reading>sheer</reading> (しる) soup.

You need to apply <vocabulary>oil</vocabulary> to <reading>a bra</reading> (あぶら) because it's stuck on you. You can't get it unhooked, so you have to slide it off. Problem is, it's too tight, which is why <reading>a bra</reading> needs oil to slide off.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 田 yet. Just think about how you walk into the <vocabulary>oil field</vocabulary> and you see a bear <reading>den</reading> (でん), filled with oil.

This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't seen the on'yomi reading for 泥 yet (でい), so here's a mnemonic to help you out: 

You'll probably get <vocabulary>dead drunk</vocabulary> if you start drinking in the middle of the <reading>day</reading> (でい). Just try to wait until the day is over, like maybe after work, you know?

The reading is the kun'yomi readings of these kanji, put together. I suppose it's because it's like two separate words put together into one. That makes this word read as <reading>うみがめ</reading>, where the かめ gets rendaku'd.

Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with the kanji, but here's a mnemonic in case you need a refresher:

Your <kanji>teardrop</kanji>s are like little waves. What are they? They're <reading>波だ</reading> (なみだ).
Remember another word that means "to measure?" It is 量る, and has the same reading as this word. That should make things easier to remember.
The reading is crazy long, but also crazy easy! You know みず means "water," and うみ means "sea." So, you have a "water sea" which is a lake, which is a <reading>みずうみ</reading>.

Your work tends <vocabulary>to be overdue</vocabulary>, so you get a lot of <reading>to-do call</reading>s (とどこおる) from your boss, reminding you to do your work. These calls are pretty annoying, but at least your work is less delayed.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
<reading>Ho nooooo</reading> (ほのお), there are flames everywhere!
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: <vocabulary>For the sake of</vocabulary> public safety, you will need to <reading>tame</reading> (ため) the wild beasts loose in our city. Now go, <reading>tame</reading> them!
The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
The reading is 熊's reading, the alternate "origin" 本 reading, and the reading for 県.
The reading comes from 蒸れる and 暑い. Know those and you know this too.
The reading comes from 蒸れる and 返す. Combine this knowledge to reheat your memories.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

The reading doesn't really make sense for the kanji, and is an exception for sure. Just think about how when you're in the <vocabulary>countryside</vocabulary> you're <reading>in 中</reading> (いなか) of nowhere.
The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them already, so you should be able to read this too!
The reading comes from 盛る and 上げる. Know those words and you'll be able to read this one too.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

You start <vocabulary>to tear</vocabulary> the cloth. You don't know if you're supposed to or not. The crowd isn't sure either. You hear kind of a <reading>yah boo</reading> (やぶ) reaction going on, making you unsure if you should continue or stop. Yah! Boo. Yah! Boo!
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
The reading is the same as 納める.
The reading is a bit weird for 納. Just imagine asking the consent question from the meaning, then have the other person say "<reading>Nahh!</reading> (なっ), no consent!"

Unfortunately, the reading for this is a complete exception, so you'll just have to memorize it. Here's a mnemonic to help you:

"You're an <vocabulary>amateur</vocabulary>!", <reading>she wrote</reading> (しろうと). A little harsh, isn't it? But that's what she wrote. Gotta do a little better to impress her, pal.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know 総理 beforehand as well.

This word uses the kun’yomi reading of both kanji. You learned また from the word 股, and you learned した from the word 下 a lonnnng time ago. If you didn't remember either of these, hang your head in shame and look at your <reading>またした</reading>!
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

This word uses the on'yomi of 自, which you learned with the kanji, and the kun'yomi of 撮, which you learned with the word 撮る. Though it's a bit of an unusual combo, you can probably guess the first one since it's such a common reading, and the second one because of the り on the end. Just watch out for rendaku, which turns とり into どり.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know 著作 first, too.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
While you go <vocabulary>to feign</vocabulary> that you're someone or something else, someone calls you out on it: "<reading>you so</reading> (よそお) much a liar!"
The reading is 裏切り and an exception reading for 者. Just think about how you'd think of a traitor as a "thing" (物) and not a person.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

The reading is a bit weird. Just think about how when you have various things, you probably have a lot of things. What do you want? You want <reading>more</reading> (もろ) of those things. <reading>More more</reading> more!
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned these readings yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Just remember that <vocabulary>rising</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>getting out of bed</vocabulary> early is the <reading>key</reading> (き) to the <reading>Sho</reading>gun's (しょう) heart. He doesn't like lazybones, so make sure to get out of bed at a reasonable time.
What is slow and probably going to be late all the time? A big <reading>oak</reading> (おく). Oaks have trouble moving, and are slow, and therefore are always late, too.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
I'm not drunk, <reading>yo</reading> (よ). YO. I'm not drunk, yo. YO. Yo, I'm not drunk. Yo.
The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji!
The readings are the readings for 酢 and the kun'yomi reading for 物 which you've seen quite a bit by now.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. The 山 reading is ざん instead of さん because of rendaku.
The reading is the same as you learned with the kanji.

meanings.meaning: To Be In Light Of Something

reading_mnemonic:
This verb uses the kun'yomi of the kanji. You haven't learned that yet, so here's mnemonic to help you:

If you want <vocabulary>to take something into account</vocabulary>, you'll need to <reading>考</reading>える (かんが) about it really hard first. Please think about it really, really carefully, because it's bound <vocabulary>to be in light of something</vocabulary>, and we need to know what that something is.

allMeanings.meaning: To Be In Light Of Something

reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

This is a jukugo word, so you use on'yomi readings. You should be familiar with the on'yomi reading for 天 already, but not for 雨. So here's a mnemonic to help you remember:

The <vocabulary>rainy weather</vocabulary> won't stop you to go catch some <reading>u</reading>ni (う). You would get wet anyway diving into the ocean to collect uni, the rainy weather doesn't affect you. You can also sell them for <reading>ten</reading> (てん) bucks a piece! The rainy weather isn't at all a problem for a uni hunting if you're making ten dollars for each, you know?
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
